title: How to Play the Hi Hat in a Drum Set

steps.title: Make sure your hi-hats are appropriately positioned in the kit.
steps.content: Make sure your hi-hats are appropriately positioned in the kit. You may want to review How to Set Up a Drum Kit to do this properly.

steps.title: Close the hi-hats.
steps.content: Close the hi-hats. Do this by either holding down the pedal with your left foot or locking the top cymbal down using the wing nut. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Play some drums,
steps.content: Play some drums, experimenting with your closed hi-hats. In many basic rock grooves, the hi-hats are usually struck on every quarter, eighth or sixteenth note. If you already have a feel for "closed" hi-hat use, learn how to start using the hi-hat pedal. [2] X Research source

steps.title: The hi-hat pedal is used to create different sounds when striking the hi-hats, and to keep time for yourself and the band during a song.
steps.content: The hi-hat pedal is used to create different sounds when striking the hi-hats, and to keep time for yourself and the band during a song. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Use the wing nut to adjust the cymbals about an inch apart.
steps.content: Use the wing nut to adjust the cymbals about an inch apart. If your foot is on the pedal holding the cymbals together, lift it up so the cymbals are not touching each other. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Practice opening and closing the hi-hats with your left foot.
steps.content: Practice opening and closing the hi-hats with your left foot. [5] X Research source One exercise is the "heel-toe" - starting with an open hi-hat and your toe pointed up, bring your toe down to close the hi-hat. Simultaneously, point your heel up. Then, switch again. After practicing this rhythmically for a minute or two, the muscles in your lower leg will start to burn. You will soon be able to do this for longer and longer, becoming more efficient in using the hi-hat pedal for long time periods.

steps.title: Loosen the hi-hat.
steps.content: Loosen the hi-hat. This is to further the two cymbals from each other that they make more of a "sizzling" sound when struck. Playing traditional rock grooves with a looser hi-hat gives more of a metal feel.

steps.title: Run some simple snare rudiments, keeping time with the hi-hats.
steps.content: Run some simple snare rudiments, keeping time with the hi-hats. As timekeeping is a primary function of the hi-hats, you should practice "clicking" or "snapping" the hats together on beat. This is usually done on each of the quarter notes (1-2-3-4) or every other eighth note (the "ands" - 1-&-2-&-3-&-4-&.)

steps.title: Start keeping beat with the hi-hats when playing various grooves.
steps.content: Start keeping beat with the hi-hats when playing various grooves. Since you're using the pedal, play the normal hi-hat part on the ride cymbal, floor tom, cowbell, or another part of the drum kit.

steps.title: Choke, or "bark," the hi-hats.
steps.content: Choke, or "bark," the hi-hats. Hold the cymbals tight with the pedal, open the hats, quickly (almost simultaneously) strike the top cymbal, and immediately close the hats with the pedal again. This technique is often applied in hip hop, blues, and motown-like genres.
